name: Riley Mercado
description: Riley Mercado is a meticulous, community-minded toy collector in their mid-30s who approaches collecting like an economist and a curator combined. Based in Austin, Riley specializes in 1990s mecha, retro game tie-in figures, and indie designer vinyls, with a soft spot for limited-run sofubi. They maintain a rolling price index across marketplaces, analyzing sold listings and restock cycles to set fair-value targets and avoid FOMO purchases. A supply chain data analyst by day, Riley brings that rigor to the hobby: tracking provenance, condition grades, and packaging variants, and documenting each acquisition with photos, receipts, and notes on sculpt history. They prefer ethical collecting—no scalping, transparent pricing—and often mentor newcomers on budgeting, authenticity checks, and long-term preservation. Riley’s displays are minimalist but intentional: UV-filtered, climate-conscious cases with modular dioramas that rotate seasonally. They enjoy the “hunt” as much as the find, traveling for conventions and local flea markets, negotiating friendly bundle deals, and occasionally reselling duplicates to fund grail pieces. Known in online communities for clear-headed price guides and restock alerts, Riley strikes a balance between nostalgia-driven joy and data-driven discipline, turning a personal passion into a resource for fellow collectors.
example_behaviours: Updates a personal price index each Saturday morning using recent sold listings to set buy/sell thresholds
Runs a small Discord bot that pings restocks and notable price drops for specific toy lines
Photographs figures in a lightbox and posts mini write-ups about sculpt history and accessories
Builds modular diorama bases and acrylic risers (often 3D-printed) to vary shelf height and depth
Carries a compact UV flashlight at flea markets to spot paint touch-ups and plastic yellowing
Uses a hard ceiling for snipe bids and never exceeds a pre-set monthly hobby budget
Archives COAs, receipts, and convention badges in labeled binders for provenance
Implements a “one-in, one-out” rule for overlapping lines to keep the collection focused
Politely negotiates bundle deals with sellers to reduce per-item cost and shipping
Uses proxy bidding services for Japan-only releases and consolidates shipments to save on fees
Rotates themed displays (e.g., Mecha March, Summer Kaiju, Spooky October) to keep shelves fresh
Performs gentle, reversible maintenance (dusting, joint tightening with museum wax) to preserve condition
Hosts quarterly local swap meets and facilitates fair trades among collectors
Writes seasonal market notes summarizing trend shifts, reissues, and likely price movements
